We ordered the "classic" cesear to start but asked them to leave off the olive tapenade and hard boiled egg (neither of which are part of a classic cesear), and it was very good-just enough dressing and a little bit of zing. Their house Italian bread and olive oil was also a nice accompaniment.  Unfortunately, Our entrees were nothing to write home about. I had the spaghetti bolignese and my spouse the squash ravioli. My pasta was luke warm and the sauce was just ok in terms of flavor. My wife's ravioli (a dish she orders whenever she finds it on the menu) lacked the character and flavor found at some of the other spots she's had it. Overall I'd have to say this is just ok-very Americanized Italian food and nothing special.

This is one of the few times when I feel the overall rating in Yelp is overstated.

I like Lombardino's. I do not always like everything they have, though.

Lombardino's is a sensible restaurant near the UW campus that uses fresh ingredients and changes their menu seasonally--if you come in at different points in the year, you will not be able to find the same dish you fell in love with a month or two ago, potentially.

I've been here three times and it's pretty solid, but not always a home run. The best thing I've had here was a White Sangria (May) and a spinach pizza (October). Their Red Sangrias aren't slouchy, but they don't taste as fantastic as they could--they lack a little bit and it shows up in taste.

The desserts I've only had once, but what I had was amazing. This place is great for upscale, but affordable dining.

I have never had Italian as good as I did when I went to Lombardino's. We had a reservation for six people at 9pm, and we called at 6pm because the party size shrank to four, but we unfortunately couldn't move the reservation up, most likely because they were booked as it was a Saturday night. We showed up at 8:30pm and were seated immediately. Our server was a little awkward but he checked back numerous times to make sure everything was great. The four of us ordered different things (two pizzas and two pasta dishes) and shared, so we each tried a few things on the menu. We stayed away from some of the seafood and beef tenderloin types of options because they were considerably more expensive. I personally started with the spaghetti alla bolognese, and the moment I began eating it I was taken aback as I had never had spaghetti anywhere near that tasty! The other pasta dish and both pizzas were both excellent as well. The wine was priced about the same as any other restaurant similar to this one. The alcohol menu had quite a few wines and cocktails available, so there were many options depending on what food you ordered. Can't wait to come back here and explore the menu some more!

When I saw the outdated exterior and decor of this restaurant, I was a bit worried. Once my entree arrived, I understood why this place is a Madison institution. I ordered a primavera pasta with seasonal vegetables (spinach, artichoke hearts, broccoli etc), and I cannot express how good the sauce was. It was a lemon cream sauce but it wasn't heavy, just light and tangy and acidic and the best. For the quality of the food, it was pretty inexpensive (although I'm from chicago where prices are outrageous). 

I am taking a star off for the decor and the Caesar salad, which was authentic with the egg and anchovy, but overdressed in my opinion. It also had this dark mystery dressing in addition to the traditional Caesar - we could not figure out what it was. All in all though this place was great and I would definitely come back the next time I'm in town.

Great Service- I had a great server that was very attentive without being intrusive.
Adorable decor- very Midwestern Italian campy (that's a style right?).
Very homey- tables are numerous and close together. Take the time to say hi to your neighbor stranger!

Okay, let's talk about the food.
Meh... Although I was not very adventurous on this visit.
What I tried:
Brussels sprout salad- lovely, lots of crunch, generous toppings and a tasty vinaigrette.

Butternut squash soup- very thick and hearty. About what you would expect.

Spaghetti alla Bolognese- it's spaghetti with meat sauce. My dad could make this (context: my father is a nice man, but a pretty awful cook. I love him very much).

Winter linguine with clams and mussels- I'm going to say it... almost as good as the Olive Garden (there are a few unclassy things in life that I like and Olive Garden is one of them)

Pizza with wild mushrooms and lardo- great thin crust, tons of cheese. Mushrooms were flavorful. Biggest disappointment, lardo is not Italian for bacon. Rookie mistake. Lardo is fat back. When the pizza came out, I just thought it was cheese that hadn't quite melted. Nope! Although the texture was not off putting and was pretty flavorless, knowing I was eating strips of plain pork fat gave me the heebee jeebees. How is this different from eating a strip of bacon you may ask? The all-important hunks of cured meat dispersed in the fat, that's how.

Tiramisu- good, the whipped cream was over whipped so was greasy, not a huge portion. I recommend not sharing, unless you like passive aggressive fighting with loved ones. Another alternative is hitting up a grocery store for Haagen-Dazs's Tiramisu gelato, which is amazing, or the Tiramisu at the bakery counter at Metcalfs (1/2 the price, 4x as big, and 90% as good).

Small, cozy, intimate non-chain restaurant right next of University Avenue, close to University Hospital. Great place for family gathering that offer Italian food. The staff was extremely helpful and really nice while accommodating some people with food allergies.
The food was great, not particularly a fan of eggplant I did try the eggplant napolitana because it just read well on the menu. And I have to admit it was excellent, cooked to perfection and very yummy. I was able to bring left overs home and had it the next day, still great.

Saturday. Make sure you have reservations. We needed up sitting at the bar for dinner. It was so busy with only one person behind the bar who was catching up on table orders; we ended up waiting a good 5 minutes before we were greeted, asked if we were eating at the bar or waiting for a table. Not his fault; the other bartender was in the back stuffing blue cheese into olives. They seriously need to consider a 3rd person behind the bar. 

Appetizer | Calamari 
Delicious, crispy, and filling. Plenty of lemon. Great tomato sauce but too much horseradish plopped in the middle of the sauce.

Dinner Entrée | Orrichette
The sauce on this pasta dish was incredible in the first two bites. A white creamy sauce with perfectly cooked pasta. The sausage was plentiful. I really didn't like the rapini in the pasta. It was a bitter bite each time so I left the rest to the side. I loved the way the dish started but then it didn't go so well. Each bite got saltier for some odd reason. I needed to take a sip of water after each bite unfortunately. 

The 4 stars is for ambiance, service and calamari. I was so pleased at first with the orrichette but then became disappointed. 

Note | They had a separate special menu and was out of the lamb ragu. Hopefully they have it next time. 

Parking | street parking because their lot is limited.

Ambience could have been a little more pleasing.  The restaurant itself is a little cramped but the food does make up for it. The Bolognese pasta dish was authentic and had a great flavor to it. Calamari was a small portion and needed seasoning but nice touch with the horseradish. Ribeye was nicely cooked to medium as requested just a little charred on the sides.

Wow.

Just got back from Lombardino's.  I arrived with my date and we were promptly seated at a bar table.  Our waiter, Matt, appeared and greeted us.  Apparently he had some sort of prior relationship with the person I was with.  No big deal - I'm here for the food.

I ordered drinks and an appetizer, as well as their signature pizza.  I hate arugula so I ordered it without.  

After taking our orders I never saw our waiter again.  I sat with an empty glass for 15-20 minutes while he sat milling around the bar, occasionally making drinks.  When my pizza finally came, it arrived with EXTRA arugula.  I sent it back and waited some more, still receiving zero attention from our waiter.  Finally I pulled aside another waitress and told her to get the check.  Immediately thereafter the correct pizza arrived, which I sent back.  The waiter who spent half the night doing nothing came over and asked if anything was wrong.  I told him we wanted the check and we were leaving.  He was a smug asshole the entire time, going so far as to box up the pizza and depart with a snarky "Take it or leave it we don't care."
 

This guy either sucks at his job or he was carrying his personal life into the workplace.  Totally unprofessional.  It's unfortunate, because I believe the reviews when they say the food here is delicious, but I will never dine here again.

A Madison institution I always wanted to try. Finally ate there tonight and really wanted to love it but it was just ok. I won't go back. 

The atmosphere was excellent old school Italian. The bread and olive oil were outstanding.  

The meatball appetizer, mushroom polenta and horseradish beef ravioli were meh.  The feature pudding desert was equivalent to Applebee's.

May be my favorite place in Madison. Great ambiance -- not pretentious, homey, but with a hint of irony. The food is top notch, and Bennet is the best bartender I've ever encountered, anywhere. And I'm a lush, so that's saying a lot. ;-)    Few places in Madison can match the food, and none have its combination of friendliness, service, quality and relaxed ambiance.

Very nice restaurant. We visit here for special event like BD etc. this time, as almost every visit, the food was very good. 
We both order the soup of the day ( asparagus) which was very very good. We had couple appetizers and main course, and tiramisu at the end. 
HOWEVER: as we start getting our food, a big group come in and our waitress serve them as well. Since they were about 12.......he didn't have time for us at all!!!  
No mater what, and also other waitresses were available, we had zero service!  So food is 5 stars but with this level of service - sport - but you get only 3 stars.

Don't reserve your table online. Tried today, received a confirmation email, and got to the restaurant only to be told it would be another 2.5 hrs. Apparently the online system doesn't sync with their in house system. If your going to have online reservations it needs to work with your in house systems. Pretty disappointed and eating at home now as every place in town is booked up!

I happened upon this place while looking for a place to get some good italian food in Madison. It was SO GOOD. I ordered the veal garganelli and for dessert, the apple doughnuts. These aren't things i would typically gravitate towards but wow, such good flavors! This chef really knows what he/she is doing. Go to Lombardino's! Order these two things! :)

"Exquisite" is a word that comes to mind. Since our first time here during last summer's restaurant week, which was just wonderful, we've been eagerly anticipating eating here for Winter's restaurant week. I'm not normally a fan of apples or dried fruits. I downright hate them. I will not buy them at the grocery store unless someone in my family requests them. However, Lombardino's has managed to turn two fruits I hate into a magical eating experience. To start our dining event, we chose the Winter Fruit Antipasti, which is a soppressata salami and gorgonzola cheese with marinated apple, pear, dried fig, and apricot salad. Marinated in what syrupy sauce, I have no clue, but it was beautiful and delicious.  For the entree, my fiance chose the Marsala Mushrooms and Spinach Pasta and I chose the Milk-Braised Jordandal Farm Pork Shoulder. We had no clue pasta could taste that wonderful! And my meal just melted in my mouth...literally. I've never had a meal that has done that.  The pork was cooked just right and the polenta with the pork braising jus was just so meltingly creamy. For dessert. we couldn't make up our minds and ordered all three - the Pistachio Cake, the Bocca Nera, and Lombardino's Tiramisu (they gave us the third dessert free of charge because our reservation was late and we weren't horrible and impatient about it.) The Pistachio Cake came with sour cream ice cream and a cherry compote. I never would have though sour cream ice cream could be a thing, much less a delicious thing. Eat all three together (cake, ice cream, and cherry compote) and you've got a delicious mixture. I enjoyed the Bocca Nera, but the chocolate was a bit too rich for me. Their tiramisu was just divine.. 

Last, but certainly not least, our server was wonderful. Chelsea has a sincere and cheery smile that was just heart-warming.

Felt like I was in an Italian restaurant immediately by the the welcome by the gracious hostess, and immediate seating. Obviously well trained, she seated incoming patrons around the restaurant instead of stacked on top of each other, to insure diners could relax and converse. We immediately had water, and we're greeted by our waiter, without question one of the most professional I have had. The menu was true Italian, no reheated Servo food here. Price point is "date night", yet not special occasion, and reasonable, portions fair. Service attentive, friendly, European. Great coffee. My companion liked his pork chops, I was taken aback by the ragu in the beef and bacon stew with horseradish tavioli. The dessert menu had something for everybody, instead of "just cheesecake" and Tira misuse that has sat too long. Now, I won't have to miss the wonderful Italian restaurants of the East side of Milwaukee. Tell Nonna I'll be back soon.

My absolute favorite restaurant in town! I come here for the pasta and pasta only. It's so hard to find a restaurant in Madison that properly seasons and cooks the pasta, but Lombardino's got it down to an art. The flavor and texture of each individual noodle in perfect, and they're so creative with the broths and sauces in top. Great seasonal menu featuring locally sourced ingredients. This is my go-to spot for showcasing Madison's culinary scene to any out of town visitors. 

You can bring your kids too as the restaurant is reasonably noisy.

Review your bill. The Stuzzichino Menu from 5pm-6pm offers special lower prices, but an unexpected higher total on my bill caught my attention. I checked the charges and found the discount was omitted. I was told I ordered at 6:11pm, which was after the 5-6pm discount timeframe. I checked my watch and it was 6:15 and I sat with bill in hand. I asked how I ordered at 6:11 if the current time was 6:15 and my meal was finished. I was told it was a glitch. The server then told me she fixed it so it was ok. No apology. Maybe it was just an error.  

Also, as I entered, I was offered the regular menu and told the discounted menu was just a dollar difference, but I compared menus and that was not true, either. 

The Caesar was good. The pizza with figs, Gorgonzola and hog jowl was good when I took the figs off. My palate isn't that sophisticated, I guess. 

Other than the issues mentioned, the experience was pretty pleasant.

Had the calamari & pizza lombardino. Calamari was not up to par. Coating was not crispy and dipping sauce was so basic and lacking in flavor... Would've been good at least with a mayo based with garlic and lemon. But the pizza lombardino was ultimate disappointment. It was a waste of arugula when the entire pizza was drowning in grease... Probably didn't take in to consideration the cheese would produce additional grease...? The crust was delicious. Sadly, did not even take leftovers. Dessert moscato- marchesi di gresy 2012 was delicious. So there's the two stars. It's overrated.

A very nice gem in the Madison area.  Had the Family with me and we were looking at colleges (UWM).  We got very hungry, and I liked the reviews at Lombardino's.  So off we went and let me tell you, knowing Italian food as I do, Chicago and all, This place is worth the stop for authentic Italian cuisine. Family all ordered what they wanted, I started out with a very nice Montepulciano Vino. Ordered the Grilled Calamari. Some ordered Lasagna, Pasta dishes with Veal Parmagiana.  Service, Ambience, attention to detail was very good.  Worth a stop.  Ciao & Cheers!

Lombardino dinner with good companies was a welcoming scene at the end of a cold, rainy Wednesday (in April, sigh).

This place makes me feel so relaxed (get the table #4 - end booth in the brick section). The wine they had on special was so delicious, and the our server was so pleasant and attentive. I like old-school service and atmosphere in restaurants, so this was very well-suited for me. 

On to the food. Appetizer calamari was good. I can't claim that it's the best - I prefer higher ratio of calamari to breading, but the seasoning was good.
Pasta dishes vegetarian Pappadelle and eggplant/tomato spaghetti was good as well. Again, not out of the world fabulous, but deserving of 3-4 stars. 

3 of us shared a desert plate - my favorite was sour-cream ice cream. That was 5 star yummy.
Yep, I broke all my vegan rules, but it was worth it. Expanding horizon is always fun.
Consistent. Nice wine list. A little too cutesy in the decor, but the best Itailian place in Madison. The spag Bolognesse is just about a perfect dish.

Yum. Yum. Yum.

Good food. Not trying too hard. Just good. This is what I love about Madison.

We started off with the pork belly. And while I'd love to say this is what nabbed me, it was the polenta. The creamy polenta, flavorful cabbage and crunchy pork belly blended together well. I could have eaten this as a meal in itself.

We then split a pizza and an entree. For starters, you can do a half and half pizza! What a great option for those indecisive people out there who read into a menu too much. (pointing a finger at myself). We tried the barbecued octopus pizza, which was tasty, (but I'm always iffy about sweet and spicy) as well as the mushroom, Frabroni's sausage and fontina pizza. The latter won us over, but is for a mushroom lovers.  What I should be mentioned is it's cooked to a beautiful, crunchy perfection in their wood-burning oven, Neapolitan style. In my opinion, the best way. I have had pizza here before and it made my tastebuds happy that it is consistently this delicious.

We finished off with the pan seared sea scallops. Four large, perfectly crisp scallops served on top of surprisingly light mashed potatoes. I found myself full but taking little bites of the potatoes and tarragon-short rib reduction just because it was delicious.

I should also note, we were both guided toward perfect wine choices through their knowledgeable staff. Much appreciated.

I'm looking forward to returning.

I've heard a lot of good things about this place, so we went here for my girlfriend's birthday.  It was the first night of their new menu, so the only real problems I had should be taken lightly since they're works in progress.

Reservation was listed as it should have been, and we were sat almost immediately.  Our server was there to get our drink order (a bottle of Syrah Blend...Cusumano I believe) quickly, and she explained the specials.  We ordered, got our bread allotment, and was off to a smooth start.  The wine was very good by the way.

The food was hit and miss, but again, this was their first night with the new menu.  We split a caesar salad, which was tasty and what I'd think of as a normal portion AFTER being split between the two of us (which they did in the kitchen).  The only problem I had was that the pumpkin ravioli tasted like pumpkin pie ravioli.  WAY too sweet, which made me wonder if they had tasted this version lately (a previous version was apparently even sweeter).  The Fraboni Sausage pasta dish was good, but didn't jump off the plate or anything...probably a good thing : )  Seriously though, it was a solid dish.  The best dish, by far, was the Hereford Filet.  We inquired as to where it was from, and I guess it's not sourced locally.  Regardless, it was perfectly cooked--medium rare--and the accompanying mushrooms, onions and sauce were delicious.

We were honest about all of this with the server, who received our commentary well when we were asked how everything was.  She also noted how the kitchen liked the constructive feedback since it was the first night with the new menu, etc.  Even if that's not true, it was nice to feel heard.

We didn't do dessert, as we have another local place that we like to frequent for that.  The desserts on the menu looked ok though, for whatever that's worth.

I think that 4 stars is definitely within reach for me here, but 3 fits this experience well.  It was "A-Ok".  I will definitely come back here again.  The ambiance is nice, it's quiet for a larger restaurant, and everyone knows what they're doing.
Probably one of my favorites in madison. The bolognese is fantastic. I've been here at least 25 times and have never had a bad experience. Service is knowledgable and polite.

Love this place. Excellent pizza, terrific calamari, outstanding specials, great wine list sll in an authentic retro setting.  Best bagguettes in Madison.  (For take out at $3 each if you want a take home treat.)
Great atmosphere, nice seasonal menu with variety of pasta/meat options. Food had nice flavor and pasta was perfectly al dente. On the pricey side for the quality of food though

First of all, our waitress was very nice. But, it took forever to get our wine, once we ordered it. The bread and dipping oil was awesome! Delicious!
Then, our waitress gave us the wrong food items.  SO, we just switched them except not realizing just how hot the soup bowl was! WOW!    
The actual meal was good.  Very tasty!  Then, we sat and waited for a long time for dessert.  They were busy.  We understand how that can go.
Then, I requested a box to go for my leftovers. Well, our waitress wrote down the the name of my dinner on the box, but, it wasn't my dinner inside the box. Have no idea whose it was.  Gross. It wasn't even close to anything anyone of us ordered at our table. Needless to say, I threw mine out.  More attention to detail is what is needed. Sad to throw out a lot of a meal, especially for what the prices were. Atmosphere was fun!  We had never been there before.  But, I have to say for what they charge, as many issues as we had, we won't be back anytime soon, if at all.  Very disappointed overall.

Make no mistake, Lombardino's is one of the best restaurants in Madison in terms of taste and value. I've eaten at Lombardino's about 25 times in the last three years and the food has been consistently excellent. 

The menu is a combination of seasonal and signature dishes. The food sublimely combines authentic italian cuisine and techniques with inventive seasonal flavors. The portions are satisfying without being overwhelming.

I highly recommend the caprese appetizer, beef carpaccio appetizer, eggplant capanata appetizer, ORECCHIETTE Pasta with FRABONI'S SAUSAGE & RAPINI dinner entree...

I could go on and on but all you really need to know is that this place rocks Balls!

I end up going to Lombardino's semi-often. It's a bit of a mix between old-school and chef-y Italian. Think longstanding old-school Italian restaurant building, with modern chef-ed up menu. 

They do a good job on the fried calamari but FYI that's horseradish in the marinara *not* parmesan cheese. I dunno what's up with midwest Italian places adding horseradish to the calamari equation. I once went to a place near Lake Geneva that gave COCKTAIL SAUCE instead of marina. That was quite a surprise. 

Most recent couple visits have been solid. This last time I had the horseradish beef ravioli and my wife had the marsala mushroom tagliatelle. Generally the pasta dishes here are not overwhelmingly large but I appreciate being able to try a few things over the course of dinner. My dish, I know it's horseradish ravioli, and I get the idea they were going for, kind of a steak sandwich with horseradish cream sauce in ravioli form, but it was a bit horseradish-forward. I still enjoyed it but I think to be truly memorable I'd prefer a more savory ravioli with a *hint* of horseradish and some other bright flavor to balance out the beef. 

I appreciate their pizzas and changing up the menu, good to share as an app sometimes as long as you're willing to commit to a carb heavy dinner. Which is fine, occasionally. 

Overall, I've always left a Lombardino's feeling happy, although I have to remind myself it's not always the cheapest, and sometimes we're like, "oh hey let's go get dinner somewhere, oh hey Lombardino's, cool," and next thing you know by the time you have apps, entrees, drinks & split a dessert it's $125 after tip for a dinner for two. Which is fine for the quality of food you get but for some reason in my mind I think of it as more casual of a place and forget that in a way, it's a "special occasion" type dinner.

Pro tip: if you can't get a reservation, you may be able to chill in the bar area for a bit then camp out on a couple stools and have a nice meal. The decor in there with the tile is nice to look at.

Mrs. T and I went here for our anniversary awhile back and we definitely will be back to mark other special occasions because -- holy cow -- these guys are amazing.

We had both ordered off of the seasonal menu because everything on it sounded amazing.

I had a braised pork and housemade mascarpone ravioli in a white sauce. The pork had its own strong flavor, it was well balanced with the smooth and light sweet of the mascarpone, and it was a symphony of flavor when you added the sauce.

Alas I can't remember what my wife had for her entree but she got stuffed kalamata olives as an appetizer and at the time she claimed she could've just eaten several more of those appetizers and walked out a happy woman.

Big on flavor -- Lombardinos is a couple of steps above your regular italian fare in Madison.

A gem of Madison. Great food and pizza. My personal favorite is the orecchiette with local cream sauce and sausage.

I benchmark calamari across the world against their fried calamari. Often this Wisconsin joint wins.

Without question the best and most consistent food in Madison. When I read these reviews I'm consistently amazed by Madison's preference for style or perceived "coolness" over substance and taste. This place is amazing! My wife and I enjoyed or anniversary there last night and decided to go small plates...braised pork cheeks over polenta, the best calamari anywhere, pizza Lombardino (prosciutto and arugula), and a half order of house made pappardelle with truffled mushrooms....all were amazing, not to mention wonderful desserts grilled ginger cake with homemade pumpkin ice cream and a caramelized banana and nutella crepe. I've probably been there 10 times and have love it everytime. Please throw out any misconceptions of this being traditional old school Italian. The food is creative and tastes incredible!

Had an early (5pm) dinner with a friend here last night.  Good service, good food.  My friend LOVED it and can't wait to go back.  I wouldn't rush back anytime soon, but I'd have no problem eating here again either.  Here are some of the highlights:

- Bread & olive oil were just OK.  Bread was cold. There was no salt or pepper on table to season the oil.

- Calamari was a pretty large portion, but overbreaded and underseasoned.

- Eggplant Napoletana was a huge portion and delicious. Linguini picchi pacchi had a good ratio of seafood to pasta.

- Panna cotta was delicious and came with lots of fruit.  Chocolate espresso budino was thick and rich, but had a gritty texture (I'm assuming from the espresso) and the hazelnut cookie crisp was cold and not so crispy.

- Nice wine and cocktail list.

- Server was friendly, efficient, and helpful.

Even at 5pm the place was packed, and we were the youngest people there by at least 20 years.  Closer to 7 when we left the median age was dropping, and the place was still jumping.

I had an amazing dinner here! It was an experience more than just food with fresh tasting local ingredients and an amazingly crafted cocktail. The wood fired trout was the most amazing piece of fish I've had in my entire life! Would also highly recommend their dessert. We tried several and were in bliss! The service was good and the ambiance felt like Venice.
Delicious Italian food. I travel across the country eating at high end restaurants. I've also lived in Italy for 6 months. Lombardino's was excellent. Spending money here makes sense.

Yum! Went here on a Sunday night, and it was delicious. We got seated immediately which was great, and the servers were very friendly and accommodating. The food was rich and delicious. I will definitely be back!

We have visited this place countless times over the years and can tell you it's a solid establishment due to the consistently well prepared food and drink. Lombardino's also tends to hire folks whom are well poised, not bubbly or perky. Simply an observation, perhaps it's more of an affect due to the the low lighting and small dining room. Most nights you'll need reservations. They produce seasonally unique dining menus and nightly specials. This is a pricey place, so just be aware you'll drop some dough. However, they let you order 1/2 portions of any of their pastas so you can eat less, or if you're like me you can just eat more than one kind of pasta! 
Cons: their dirty martinis tend to taste garlicky. Not my thing. 
Pros: wide variety of foods, always been good, consistently. Allow for 1/2 orders on all their pastas!
Don't be fooled if you remember a run of the mill italian place from your childhood.  Ownership change 10ish years ago put lombardinos amongst the best in Madison.

We stopped in due to the fact that it was right across the street from our hotel. What a nice surprise. We had the mushroom tagliatelle, pasta bolagnaise , calamari veal. All were very nice, our waiter, Kurt was very helpful in helping us decide.

I wish the olive oil and bread wasn't cold. Otherwise it was quality.
Seats are pretty tight; would hate to be overweight in this case.
Food was pretty good. Would like to go back again to try something else.
Everything was fabulous, from the yummy appetizer to the end dessert. Great wait staff.

I blame myself. My expectations were high. Not sure why, but they were.

I found no fault, per se, in any of the dishes we ordered, yet I wasn't blown away. I didn't have that eager-for-the-next-bite kinda feeling that I always hope for; everything just seemed average.

As usual, our party ordered an appetizer of calamari to enjoy alongside the complimentary bread and olive oil. No complaints. Though I didn't dig into either too much.


As far as entrees, we ordered:

*Butter pasta and parmesan

*Wood-grilled paprika sausage and octopus w. red potatoes, chickpeas, swiss chard, san marzano tomato, and saffron aioli

*Chicken milanese of parmesan and breadcrumb chicken w. salsa verde and fried egg, served on polenta

*Orechiette with fraboni's sausage and rapini w. roasted garlic-steeped cream and a splash of brandy

*8oz cider brined pork loin chop w. yukon golds, seared escarole, grilled lemon & tuscan olive oil 


Of everything that we ordered, what most stands out for me as enjoyable was the pork loin chop. I was able to try a few bites and quite enjoyed the dish. 

So I wouldn't rule this place out right away. I plan on giving it another try, as some other dish may pleasantly surprise me.

Eaten here multiple times. Amazing, dim lit, warm, classy environment. There Cesar salad is always a great start, and there specials and seasonal pastas are my go to. Every entree I've had has given me chills.
My all time favorite restaurant in Madison.  Last night had the lamb ragu with linguini- excellent!!!  Pizza Lombardino is always a winner.

I love Lombardino's.  The food is not authentic Italian.  Rather it is Italian that has taken on a Midwestern twist.  Which is fine, but you just need to go in with that attitude.  The interior is romantic and charming.  The food can be a little on the heavy side.  Sometimes a little too rich with a tad too much cream and too much cheese.  Still solid overall.

Ohhhh Lombardinos....I want to like you so bad...but! Ok turn up the lights! Starting with having to use the flashlights on our phones to see the menu should have tipped us off! When you can't see your food at all it's really too dark especially when you start wondering what the dark gloppy stuff is on your plate ! Five of us dined last night with a whopping $355 bill before tip and the waitstaff couldn't have been less engaged- doing their job but so dis-interested in our dining experience and ill-informed it was laughable! "Oh gosh I forgot what was in the special again" the scallop dish used small scallops three to be exact instead of the proper size #10s for a dinner entree at $29... the red peas?? Huh??? Were hard and raw and tasteless and the roast parsnips hard, we couldn't see what else was in the dish but all three of us left it at the bottom after we ate the tasty scallops- I was pleasantly surprised when I was told I could do two 1/2 entrees and got to try the rabbit ragu and ravioli (delicious) and my old favorite eggplant parmesan napoleon (tasty but you're not cooking your eggplant enough as it's hard and raw in the middle!) when posed with appetizers suggestions to share for five we settled on calamari and the bruschetta after I asked the waitress to add to the order so there were enough for all of us she presented two plates with two pieces of bread on each and a knife! What??!?! Salads were tasty and fresh- not sure if we misunderstood how the ice cream dessert was supposed to be ordered but when the five tiny single scoops of salted caramel ice cream arrived we'd wished we'd have ordered more! Is that really how it's served? A golf ball scoop per person or were we supposed to order the three scoop dessert and mix the flavors...again- stepford waitress and her giggly explanation left us wanting more of the delicious ice cream but by then she was no where in site- our reservation was at 7pm and we were the last guests in an empty ghost town of an aging Italian restaurant at 9pm! Will come back again probably but would really like to be wowed like the old days! At close to $450 including tip (two bottles of wine) things should have been stellar and visible!

Found this place on Yelp extremely average $32 for pasta bolognaise a Caesar salad and a small glass of Chianti for $17 I figured the pasta would be homemade nope out of a box I asked if the Caesar salad was traditionally made since it was a laCarte I was told yes I ordered it one minute later the very average pre-made Caesar salad appeared I'm from Chicago so I know Italian this is a step above olive garden

We went for dinner, and just loved it.  I had 1/2 ORECCHIETTE with FRABONI'S SAUSAGE & RAPINI, and 1/2 SPICY SAUSAGE & CLAMS, and hubby had WOOD GRILLED PAPRIKA SAUSAGE & OCTOPUS.  Both of us loved our dishes.  The sausage and clams have a very nice fire to them.  Get's ya sweating just a bit.  The Orecchiette was just plain delicious.  I would order both again.  I love the fact that they will let you do 1/2 & 1/2 orders of pasta!  Hubby loved his Octopus.  Said the sausage wasn't anything special tho.
For dessert, we had the Brioche french toast, and hubby had a chocolate pot de creme.  Both were quite good.
We will be going back.

Not much to add. An older established Italian restaurant on the west-side. Not snooty. No need to be all dressed up but OK if you wanted to make it special.  Excellent food. Service was great. The Spring lamb ragu on pasta was rich and wonderful. The fresh white anchovy pizza was exceptional. I paired it with an Italian pinot noir/cab blend.  Perfect!  S.U. had seared scallops on a beef ragu on bacalao (salt-cod) mashed potatoes. Wow! 

We're only in town for a few days but I'll try to make it back for another pie.
